qas.question: What were the trigonometric functions that Aryabhata discovered?

answers.text: sine, versine, cosine and inverse sine

qas.question: What theory did Brahmagupta suggest in 628 AD?

answers.text: gravity was a force of attraction

qas.question: What did Brahmagupta use the number zero for?

answers.text: a placeholder and a decimal digit

qas.question: What language did the work of Brahmagupta and Aryabhata have to be translated from?

context: Indian astronomer and mathematician Aryabhata (<a0_0>476-550<a0_0/>), in his Aryabhatiya (499) introduced a number of trigonometric functions (including <a1_0>sine, versine, cosine and inverse sine<a1_0/>), trigonometric tables, and techniques and algorithms of algebra. In 628 AD, Brahmagupta suggested that <a2_0>gravity was a force of attraction<a2_0/>. He also lucidly explained the use of zero as both <a3_0>a placeholder and a decimal digit<a3_0/>, along with the Hindu-Arabic numeral system now used universally throughout the world. <a4_0>Arabic<a4_0/> translations of the two astronomers' texts were soon available in the Islamic world, introducing what would become Arabic numerals to the Islamic World by the 9th century. During the 14th–16th centuries, the Kerala school of astronomy and mathematics made significant advances in astronomy and especially mathematics, including fields such as trigonometry and analysis. In particular, Madhava of Sangamagrama is considered the "founder of mathematical analysis".
